messages: 75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (22:45): if I cannot directly connect a database
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (22:46): hali: but connect a server(let us call it server A) firstly using ssh xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx, then connect server B which has database
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (22:46): using ssh xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx. Then I may sqlplus that database
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (22:47): hali: my question is that my I use remote client to connect that database?
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (22:47): or remote application?
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (22:48): cguo: assuming the listener is running, there are no firewall restrictions, and you have your client setup properly, it should work
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (22:48): you could even tunnel through SSH if that's all you've got (but i don't recommend it)
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (22:49): prevus: thanks, I willgoogle for ssh tunnel
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (22:50): if you can get into the server with ssh, why not just use the local sqlplus client?
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (22:50): even thought you don't recommend it, there is no way if I cannot connect from
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (22:51): well like pravus said you can tunnel the ports, but if u can get ssh access, you should be able to run sqlplus on the remote server
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (22:51): unless you want to run some application over the connection
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (22:51): but thats alittle crazy
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (22:52): English: yeah, I need to run discoverer desktop to connect database remotely:(
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (22:52): well you need to know which ports you need, and then foward them
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (22:52): use putty, and google for tunneling
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (22:53): vnc and tunneling would be a good example
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:07): we used to run a database/app connection through an ssh tunnel... what a nightmare
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:12): pravus: :) a question
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:13): when I download oracle stuff
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:13): there are two thing:Oracle Business Intelligence
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:13): and Oracle Business Intelligence tools
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:15): no idea... i'm only familiar with the DB products
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:24): hi, pravus, if I ssh machine1, then ssh machine2 in machine1
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:24): then sqlplus the database in machine2
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:24): but may I use the ssh tunnel to deal with such a case?
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:24): there is no sqlplus installed in machine1
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:25): cguo: yes... something like:   ssh -L 1521:localhost:1521 user@machine2 # from machine1
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:25): then you should be able to connect to machine1 on port 1521 and it will tunnel to machine2's port 1521
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:26): so both port number should be the same, right?
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:26): they don't have to be
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:27): but I just tried this way and seems it is out of work
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:28): you have to make sure that ssh forwarding (TCPFoward ?) is enabled in the sshd config
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:28): I understand, I use the diff way, let me try your way:)
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:28): just read up on the -L and -R options to ssh
8462e46bc281be6b36940ecbc0823fc5 (23:29): is lsmith here?
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (23:29): yes
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:29): pravus: and how may I set up the ip address in the client?
8462e46bc281be6b36940ecbc0823fc5 (23:29): do you have time to look at a small issue for me?
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:30): is it right set up to machine1's ip address?
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:30): cguo: i generally use tnsnames.ora (you would set the server name to the localhost if on machine1)
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:30): cguo: that would probably work
8462e46bc281be6b36940ecbc0823fc5 (23:30): http://rafb.net/paste/results/3QNlbe34.html
8462e46bc281be6b36940ecbc0823fc5 (23:30): I'm trying to make a really generic query that I can reuse for multiple things
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:30): netstat -an | grep LIST | grep <port>  # you can see which interface(s) the tunnel is bound to
8462e46bc281be6b36940ecbc0823fc5 (23:30): but I'm getting the error that the second oci_bind is an invalid number / name
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (23:31): '%:searchterm%'
abe59155aa41ae19e4ea964e9dd4b200 (23:31): http://www.bagdadsoftware.de")
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (23:31): that doesnt look right
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (23:31): fold the % into the variable you bind
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:31): i don't think you can embedd placeholders in strings within the query
8462e46bc281be6b36940ecbc0823fc5 (23:31): hmm ok, I can do that
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (23:32): "%$searchterm%"
8462e46bc281be6b36940ecbc0823fc5 (23:32): yeah I guess that's not the part that could be insecure anyway
8462e46bc281be6b36940ecbc0823fc5 (23:33): well thanks
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:35): pravus: oh but the problem is that I don't have sqlplus in machine1
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:36): pravus: I only can set up the tnsnames.ora in the local machine
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:36): cguo: well yeah... you'd need that installed
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:36): oh, so you want to double-tunnel?  you can do that
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:36): it's slower, but works
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (23:38): pravus: seems my situation is complicated, right:)
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:39): cguo: not really.  tunnel localhost -> machine1 and then tunnel machine1 -> machine2
607c4806ca15b47dcc0effd779440d55 (23:39): two steps instead of one
18a2305ad9994cf1c6f00729b10f1bc9 (23:40): Do you know a sql monitor for Linux??

18a2305ad9994cf1c6f00729b10f1bc9 (23:53): rizzo: a tool that show the command executing on the database
37d2de30a27c46d835b1351ae69ab8be (23:53): Brocolis: you want to see other sessions?
18a2305ad9994cf1c6f00729b10f1bc9 (23:53): rizzo: like: user rizzo Command: select * from table;
